Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Developing a Concept Inventory for Engineering Design Graphics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Engineering graphics is one of the largest enrollment courses within engineering and engineering technology; however, much of engineering graphics education today teaches the "CAD tool of the day" rather than the fundamental concepts. This project will conduct educational research in the development of a concept inventory for engineering graphics concepts that can be used by STEM educators to help a wide spectrum of students. Concept Inventories have been developed for many fundamental courses in the STEM fields. Most notably, the Force Concept Inventory developed in the early 1980s, sparked a reform in physics education that focused more on student understanding of fundamental concepts rather than rote memorization of facts. Hence Concept Inventories enable faculty to design their courses with a focus on the fundamentals and provide them with a validated means of assessing student understanding of these basic concepts. Since students enroll in engineering graphics within high schools, community colleges, and four-year institutions, this project holds great potential to improve the learning of fundamental concepts in engineering graphics for many students.

In a prior NSF project DUE-1044269, the research team used a Delphi Study to identify the fundamental concepts in engineering graphics. This project will develop its inventory based on those previously identified fundamental concepts. The instrument will be developed through a rigorous research and development process and will fill a gap in engineering and technology education. The project results will be disseminated broadly and will be targeted to faculty from a wide array of institutions, including high schools, community colleges, and four-year colleges. The project results will be long lasting within the engineering graphics education community of scholars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineering graphics is one of the largest enrollment courses within engineering and engineering technology; however, much of engineering graphics education today teaches the "CAD tool of the day" rather than the fundamental concepts. Through this project a concept inventory for engineering graphics was developed that can be used by STEM educators to help a wide spectrum of students. Concept Inventories have been developed for many fundamental courses in the STEM fields. Most notably, the Force Concept Inventory developed in the early 1980s, sparked a reform in physics education that focused more on student understanding of fundamental concepts rather than rote memorization of facts. Hence Concept Inventories enable faculty to design their courses with a focus on the fundamentals and provide them with a validated means of assessing student understanding of these basic concepts. Since students enroll in engineering graphics within high schools, community colleges, and four-year institutions, the results from this project have the potential to improve the learning of fundamental concepts in engineering graphics for many students.

In a prior NSF project (DUE-1044269), the research team used a Delphi Study to identify the fundamental concepts in engineering graphics. The Engineering Graphics Concept Inventory was developed based on those previously identified fundamental concepts. The instrument was developed through a rigorous research and development process and fills a gap in engineering and technology education, particularly in the area of assessing student learning outcomes. The resulting concept inventory includes 30 multiple-choice items that have been validated through multiple rounds of testing with thousands of students across the nation. The project results have been disseminated broadly and targeted to faculty from a wide array of institutions, including community colleges and four-year colleges. The instrument has been developed for electronic delivery and is hosted on a site that specializes in hosting instruments for assessing student learning in STEM--connectingstem.org.
